paragraphs.title: CO2 Impact of Flights Leaving Barcelona

paragraphs.text:
%md 
In this project we were aming to analyze CO2 footprint of the flights that left Barcelona and are in the sky for the duration of the presentation (10min).
Our second step was possibility to extend the research into CO2 footprint created by these planes by the time they reach their final destination for which we needed coordiantes of all destination airports in order to calculate the distance.

In addition to this, we also covered the overview statistics of planes in the air, as well as comparative statistics of CO2 emitted to the one emitted by people and cars.

%md
As it comes to the data, it has not been perfect. We ran multiple API queries looking for the fullest data set, however live data tends to be incomplete. Due to different fuel consumption for different flight range we also had to fill some gaps as classification of ranges is not clearly defined. So we had situations where flight was on an aircraft that is commonly used for short flight was flying regional and did not have statistics assigned. We also had to filter out CodeShare flights when same flight has more than one flight code attached. All in all most of the data is fairly reliable. Downside - fixing data requires manual input that is not compatible with live demonstration we wanted to do. 

Data sources that have been used:

For current flights in the sky:
Aviation Edge API

For locations and codes of all aiports:
https://datahub.io

For statisticts of airline fuel efficiency:
Web Scraping https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_aircraft

For the connection between aircraft code and aircraft name:
https://github.com/jpatokal/openflights/blob/master/data/planes.dat

For Connection between airline name and airline code:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jpatokal/openflights/master/data/airlines.dat

paragraphs.title: Conection to database
paragraphs.text:
import sqlalchemy
import pymysql
from sqlalchemy import create_engine
import pandas as pd

driver = 'mysql+pymysql'
ip = '35.246.218.28'
username = 'reports'
password = 'reports'
db = 'flight_radar'

cs  = f'{driver}://{username}:{password}@{ip}/{db}'
engine = create_engine(cs)

%md 
This is the query we used to extract only the information we are interested for our analysis. It selects all needed fields, fills in missing values for certain fields with averages.
Tables are joined with Left join to maintain maximum data from the table of flight in the air. Grouped by reg_number to filter out code sharing flights. And last filtered by date as we had appended two API calls while looking for the best sample.

paragraphs.title: Querry to Database
paragraphs.text:
Ssql = '''SELECT 
    reg_number AS flight,
    MAX(aircraft_iata) AS aircraft_iata,
    MAX(aircraft_name) AS aircraft_name,
    MAX(airline_name) AS airline_name,
    MAX(arrival) AS destination,
    MAX(airports_distance.`range`) AS flight_range,
    MIN(distance_to_bcn) AS 'distance to bcn',
    MIN(total_speed) AS speed,
    MIN(flights_dx.latitude) AS act_latitude,
    MIN(flights_dx.longitude) AS longitude,
    IFNULL(MIN(`Fuel burn (kg/km)`),
            (SELECT 
                    ROUND(AVG(`Fuel burn (kg/km)`), 2)
                FROM
                    aircrafts_features
                WHERE
                    `Flight Range` = MAX(airports_distance.`range`)
                GROUP BY `Flight Range`)) AS fuel_burn,
    IFNULL(MIN(ROUND(`total_speed` * (10.0 / 60.0) * `Fuel burn (kg/km)` * 3.0)),
            ROUND(MIN(`total_speed` * (10.0 / 60.0) * 3.0) * (SELECT 
                            ROUND(AVG(`Fuel burn (kg/km)`), 2)
                        FROM
                            aircrafts_features
                        WHERE
                            `Flight Range` = MAX(airports_distance.`range`)
                        GROUP BY `Flight Range`))) AS `Co2 (kg/10min)`,
    IFNULL(MIN(ROUND(distance_to_bcn * `Fuel burn (kg/km)` * 3.0)),
            ROUND(MIN(distance_to_bcn * 3.00) * (SELECT 
                            ROUND(AVG(`Fuel burn (kg/km)`), 2)
                        FROM
                            aircrafts_features
                        WHERE
                            `Flight Range` = MAX(airports_distance.`range`)
                        GROUP BY `Flight Range`))) AS `Co2 (flight)`,
		MAX(updated_time) as `updated_time`
FROM
    flights_dx
        LEFT JOIN
    airports_distance ON flights_dx.arrival = airports_distance.iata
        LEFT JOIN
    aircrafts_iata ON flights_dx.aircraft_icao = aircrafts_iata.icao
        LEFT JOIN
    aircrafts_features ON aircrafts_features.Model = aircraft_name
        AND aircrafts_features.`Flight Range` = airports_distance.`range`
        LEFT JOIN
    airlines_icao ON airlines_icao.airline_ICAO = flights_dx.airline_icao
GROUP BY reg_number
HAVING NOT ISNULL(flight_range) And DAY(`updated_time`) = 21
ORDER BY 1 DESC
;
'''

data = pd.read_sql(Ssql,engine)
data.info()

msg.data:
<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
RangeIndex: 62 entries, 0 to 61
Data columns (total 14 columns):
flight             62 non-null object
aircraft_iata      62 non-null object
aircraft_name      58 non-null object

destination        62 non-null object
flight_range       62 non-null object
distance to bcn    62 non-null int64
speed              62 non-null float64
act_latitude       62 non-null float64
longitude          62 non-null float64
fuel_burn          62 non-null float64
Co2 (kg/10min)     62 non-null float64
Co2 (flight)       62 non-null float64

paragraphs.title: Comparison between Kg CO2 emitted by flights in 10 min vs the CO2 emitted by population of BCN and Catalonia
paragraphs.text:
%md 
We want to compare the CO2 emitted by BCN flights vs the CO2 emitted by the population of BCN and Catalonia in 10 min time space. All values are normalized to 10 min.

co2_people_10min = {'Barcelona - 10min breathing' : 1600000*0.9/144, 'Catalonia - 10min breathing' : 7500000*0.9/144, 'Europe - 10min breathing' : 741000000*0.9/144, 'Total Human Population - 10min breathing' : 7691000000*0.9/144}

df_co2_people_10min = pd.DataFrame(co2_people_10min,  index=[0])

df_co2_people_10min['BCN flights'] = data.sum()['Co2 (flight)']
df_co2_people_10min['BCN 10 min flights'] = data.sum()['Co2 (kg/10min)']

%sql
SELECT * FROM df_co2_people_10min

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
Barcelona - 10min breathing	Catalonia - 10min breathing	Europe - 10min breathing	Total Human Population - 10min breathing	BCN flights	BCN 10 min flights
10000.0	46875.0	4631250.0	48068750.0	1977193.0	69995.0

paragraphs.text:
%md
This plot shows that the CO2 Kg emission is similar to the CO2 emitted for the people from Barcelona or Catalonia.

paragraphs.title: Equivalence of the Kg of CO2 that all flights from BCN produced in 10 min vs CO2 emissions of cars and persons.
paragraphs.text:
%md
We want to know to how many cars and how many people equals the emission of the flights in BCN in 10 min time space. All values are normalized to 10 min.

# Average Kg of CO2 emissions in 10 min/ car. Average of all cars in US, driving or stopped, according to United States Environmental Protection Agency
eq_cars = 0.0875

# Kg of CO2 emissions that an average new car (115g/km) driving at 50km/hour for 10 min, according to European Environment Agency
eq_new_cars = 0.95833 * 1000

# Kg of CO2 that 1000 exales every 10 min
people_breath = 0.00625 * 1000000

# Total number of CO2 kg emitted in 10 min by BCN flights
total_flights = 62


df_comparison = pd.DataFrame({'Total flights in 10 min' : total_flights, 'Number of persons equivalent to BCN flights - 10 min (in millions)' : (df_co2_people_10min['BCN 10 min flights'][0] /people_breath) , 'Number of new cars running at 50km/h equivalent to BCN flights (in thousands)' : (df_co2_people_10min['BCN 10 min flights'][0] /eq_new_cars) }, index =[0])

%sql
SELECT * FROM df_comparison

%md
This plot shows that every flight that leaves BCN emits the equivalent to circa 1000 cars or 200.000 people. Plus, the emission of all 62 flights equals circa the breathing of the population of Sweden.

paragraphs.title: How much people does it take to create same amount of CO2 as current planes in the sky flying for 10 min
paragraphs.text: data["Co2 (kg/10min)"].sum()*144

%md
This is almost the equivalent of whole population of Sweden.

paragraphs.title: How much people does it take to create same amount of CO2 as least efficient plane currently in the sky flying for 10 min
paragraphs.text: data["Co2 (kg/10min)"].max()*144

%md
That is an equivalent of 1,5 of Gibraltar population in 10 min alone!

%md
With this analysis we discover how much CO2 is emmited by the flights that leaves BCN at a certain time point. In different graphs, we compare the amount of CO2 emitted by the planes vs the emission caused by cars and by the breathing of huge quantity of persons. 
We conclude that the flights from BCN at a certain time point emit a very large quantity of CO2 that should make us think about using this contaminant kind of transport.
paragraphs.title: Conclusion
Further questions
paragraphs.text:
%md
* Statistics calculated taking into acount CO2 emmission per seat (data on seats per aircraft avaiable in the database)
* More API calls could be run to create a set of data for the whole week and do comparisons by day orto compare between departure airports
